STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 26, 2024
Linda Su Needham
Monroe County DHHS
903 S Telegraph Rd,
Monroe, MI, 48161-5538
RE: License#: CP580201306
Dear Ms. Needham:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 3/7/2024 . An Exit conference was held with you on 3/20/2024. Due to the violations
of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
Enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP580201306
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Linda SUE Needham
Name of Agency: Monroe County DHHS
Agency Address: 903 S TELEGRAPH RD
MONROE, MI 48161-5538
Agency Telephone #: 3132437203
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1989
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 3/4/2024-3/7/2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed

Homes pending licensure 7 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 11 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 3 3
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 2 2

in foster care since last inspection 1 1
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 46 6

since the last inspection 2 2

Open child adoption cases

Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
1 of 3 closed foster home records reviewed showed the family requested
voluntary closure of their foster home on 9/20/2023; and the agency's 11/8/2023
recommendation to the department was not at least 15 calender days of the
foster home’s 11/12/2023 license expiraton date.
Repeat Violation:
March 2022 Renewal inspection, CAP approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report that includes
all the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included
in the report.

1 of 2 special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation of all places of
contacts or types of contacts with all persons interviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to
the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
1 of 4 closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of all
aspects of (a) and (b) as required by the rule. The documentation was left blank.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 16 updated service plans(USP) reviewed(related to 1 of 6 open foster child
records reviewed) was 15 days late.
Repeat Violation:
March 2022 Renewal inspection, CAP approved on 4/18/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
2 of 3 initial service plans(ISP) reviewed (related to 2 of 6 open foster child
records reviewed) did not show documentation of (c) as required by the rule.

CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
(1) When an agency terminates it independent living
service for a youth, the agency shall document all of the
following information in the case record within 30
calendar days of termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the needs that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
1 of 2 closed independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of all aspects of (c) and (d) as required by the rule. The
documentation was left blank.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Placement preservation/disruption-At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting- Within 30 calendar
days after the child’s 14th birthday and every six
months thereafter.
4 of 6 open foster child records reviewed, and 1 of 3 open independent living
youth records reviewed, did not show compliance:
• Three open child records did not show documentation of an FTM for the
respective child's 11/11/2023-2024, 2/1/2023-5/1/2023 and 7/19/2023-
10/13/2023 USP. The FTM was either completed before the required
period or after it.

• A fourth open child's record did not show documentation of a FTM for the
child's change of placement from a shelter to a relative.
• The independent youth’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the youth's 8/23/2023-11/20/2023 USP. Nor documentation of a semi-
annual transition meeting due by 1/21/2024.
Repeat Violation:
April 2023 Interim inspection, CAP approved on 6/16/2023.
March 2022 Renewal inspection, CAP approved on 4/18/2022.
FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
2 of 19 open foster child service plans reviewed (related to 2 of 6 open foster
child records reviewed) and 1 of 10 open independent living youth service plans
reviewed (related to 1 of 3 independent youth records reviewed) did not show
compliance:
• One child’s 10/12/2023-11/10/2023 ISP was not signed by the birth mother
until 3/8/2024.
• A second child’s 12/7/2023-1/5/2024 ISP was not signed by the birth
mother until 2/29/2024, and not signed by the caregiver until 3/8/2024.
• The independent living youth’s 5/31/2023-8/22/2023 USP was not signed
by the youth until 1/3/2024.
Repeat Violation:
April 2022 Renewal inspection, CAP approved on 4/18/2022; cited under
ISEP 6.19 (5) (c).

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12509(3)(g)- Independent living record.
• The agency was apprised its documentation showing proof of the youth’s
budget for a specific month/quarter shall be signed for that specific date.
R400.12420(1) (g)Updated service plan.
• The agency is apprised its behavior support plan for each child, inclusive of
toddlers shall be clearly indicated.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12507 Medical dental and mental health care.
• The agency is advised obtaining the youth’s signature on the medical refusal
form prior to a medical/dental due date may aid it in showing clearer compliance
to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
This incident related to an allegation that the foster father exposed the couple’s two
adopted sons to sexual maltreatment. The investigation revealed the foster parents
had not disclosed mental health treatment and law enforcement involvement to the
agency. During the investigation the foster father admitted to his sexual
maltreatment of both of his adoptive children. The foster home was found in
violation of a number of foster home licensing rules, inclusive of foster home
applicant/licensee qualifications; foster home evaluation; unusual incident
notification; reporting suspected child abuse or neglect; and reporting foster home
changes. Revocation of the foster home’s license was recommended by the
agency; and the department’s action on that recommendation is currently pending.
The agency adhered to all departmental timeframes and requirements related to
this incident.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one corrective action plan during this reporting period. The
corrective action plan related to the agency's 2023 Interim inspection where the
agency received the following rule violations:
• R400.12327(60(a)-(c) Special evaluation.
• R400.12413(1)(c) medical and dental policy.
• R400.12502(2) Program statement.
• R400.12503(3) Policy and procedures.
• R400.12504 (2)(a) Eligibility requirements.
• R400.12504(2) (e)-(f) Eligibility requirements.
• R400.12509(3)(g) Independent living record.
• R400.12509(3)(o) Independent living record.
• R400.12510(1)(a) Independent living contract.
• R400.12510(2) Independent living contract.
• 722-6B Family Team meeting.
• FOM 801-C Medical passport.
The agency made progress on this CAP; of which was illustrated by
the records reviews and indicated by staff. The administration also
provided proof of completion of training with licensing staff on special
evaluations on 6/12/2023; foster care staff on family team meetings
and medical passports on 6/20/2023; and proof of the development
of an independent living checklist form; as well as an example of
quarterly document reviews by supervisors with workers all
correlating with the USP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency provided a revised chief administrator's report dated 3/21/2024 for the
period 4/20/2023- 4/19/2024. The CA reported the agency’s work staff has
remained extremely stable; and it has focused on R400.12502 and family team
meetings related to independent living due to its last inspection rule violations in
that area. Additionally, the staff teams have focused on increasing the timeliness
of medical and dental examinations, and to that end medical passport
completions. The CA report indicated the agency will be looking at its historic
CAP activities, and assessing what is working well and what requires modification.
The CA indicated barriers and factors that impacted agency rule/policy compliance
at time is general human interface of issues that surface. The CA indicated an
agency strength is its ability to have resources within the community; and workers’
ability to help families find strengths and supports, all geared to assure a child’s
safety within their environments. The agency also indicated it needs to work on
obtaining more foster homes who will accept general teens, youths on the autism
spectrum, and ones with mental health diagnoses.

Financial Overview
NA
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to discussion with the chief administrator, the program manager and
three supervisors, two foster care workers and one licensing worker were
interviewed.
The workers reported positives about the agency, with respective to it operating a
positive, no drama work environment, where employees strive and learn together.
Additionally, that administrators are approachable, there is an abundance of
trainings offered, staff strengths are encouraged and there are services to
motivate staff. An area of needed growth reported was for more staff, for their
child protective services colleagues.
Two of three independent living youths were interviewed. Both youths reported
their workers listen to them, cares for them, and the program has helped them to
gain a greater level of independence. An area of needed growth reported by one
youth was for workers to follow up on requests timely.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility did not find any concerns or safety issues.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert this inspection received on 1/31/2024.
Concern:
No operable smoke detector on each level of occupancy and /or near all sleeping
areas; and no operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution:
The agency spoke with the relative about the safety alert and provided the relative
with combination smoke/carbon monoxide detectors during an office visit by the
relative for a parenting time visit. On 2/2/2024 the worker conducted a home visit
and confirmed that the detectors were installed. The detectors were observed in
each bedroom and the main level of the home and upstairs. Photos were provided
showing the installation.
Concern:
The basement of the home was not viewed due to the caregiver indicating she was
afraid of the basement. The basement needs to be observed.
Resolution:
The agency worker made a home visit to the relative’s home on 2/2/2024 and viewed
the basement. The basement was reported to be an unfinished Michigan basement

which is not used for any daily living. The basement was reported to not be a present
safety concern. Photos of the area were provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
March 22, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 26, 2024
